result.markdown: --- title: "Ordination" author: "Michael Liou" date: "2022-12-19" execute: cache: true --- ::: {.callout-note appearance="minimal" icon=false} The following document is a work in progress! ::: ::: {.cell hash='ordination_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-1_4b9089c601f842684e03c9995e65a0b6'} ```{.r .cell-code code-summary="Libraries"} library(vegan) library(xlsx) library(skimr) library(janitor) library(tidyverse) library(ggbiplot) library(ca) library(CCA) ``` ::: ## Overview Methods to Distinguish - Correspondance Analysis (CA) - unconstrained, compare to PCA - Redundancy Analysis (RDA) - Canonical correspondance Analysis (CCA) - Canonical Correlation Analysis (CCorA) - Discriminant Analysis (DA) - PCA - Factor Analysis - NMDS - MDS General Packages - `PCA::` Software functions - `prcomp` - PCA - `princomp` - PCA - `cmdscale()` - mds - `factanal()` - factor analysis - `labdsv::pca` - `ade4::` ## Organizing Types of Ecological Data An ecological data matrix generally has the format of a main "response" matrix, with counts of species (columns) at each site (rows). We will generally have another data frame with the covariates describing each site, called the "environmental covariate" matrix and "species covariates" matrix. ## PCA There are a few ways to do a PCA in R. In order of preferred use, - prcomp - svd - princomp - eigen We'll use USArrests example to show the similarity between all the program functionality ::: {.cell hash='ordination_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-2_f15ea51ec948c7bac0a723bdf3e575e8'} ```{.r .cell-code} USArrests %>% head() # This is what the data looks like ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Murder Assault UrbanPop Rape Alabama 13.2 236 58 21.2 Alaska 10.0 263 48 44.5 Arizona 8.1 294 80 31.0 Arkansas 8.8 190 50 19.5 California 9.0 276 91 40.6 Colorado 7.9 204 78 38.7 ``` ::: ::: ::: {.panel-tabset} ### prcomp `prcomp` uses `svd` under the hood, and is generally the main workhorse for doing principal components analysis. ::: {.cell hash='ordination_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-3_1d396928312eeaafe9c0315d14766bec'} ```{.r .cell-code} us_pr <- prcomp(USArrests, scale = TRUE) us_pr$sdev^2 # the variances ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 2.4802416 0.9897652 0.3565632 0.1734301 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} us_pr$rotation ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` PC1 PC2 PC3 PC4 Murder -0.5358995 0.4181809 -0.3412327 0.64922780 Assault -0.5831836 0.1879856 -0.2681484 -0.74340748 UrbanPop -0.2781909 -0.8728062 -0.3780158 0.13387773 Rape -0.5434321 -0.1673186 0.8177779 0.08902432 ``` ::: ::: ### eigen `eigen` is the standard diagonalization technique, with the variance explained extracted in ::: {.cell hash='ordination_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-4_10eef615cac09fc403595858632fe566'} ```{.r .cell-code} us_Y <- cov(USArrests %>% scale(center = TRUE, scale = TRUE)) us_Y <- cor(USArrests) # the same as cov of centered matrix us_eig <- eigen(us_Y) # variances us_eig$values ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 2.4802416 0.9897652 0.3565632 0.1734301 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} us_eig$vectors # loadings ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [,1] [,2] [,3] [,4] [1,] -0.5358995 0.4181809 -0.3412327 0.64922780 [2,] -0.5831836 0.1879856 -0.2681484 -0.74340748 [3,] -0.2781909 -0.8728062 -0.3780158 0.13387773 [4,] -0.5434321 -0.1673186 0.8177779 0.08902432 ``` ::: ::: ### princomp uses `eigen` under the hood, mostly here for compatibility reasons ::: {.cell hash='ordination_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-5_fad09686292585fbac5c6328caf03dba'} ```{.r .cell-code} # correlation version us_prin <- princomp(USArrests, cor = TRUE) us_prin$sdev^2 ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Comp.1 Comp.2 Comp.3 Comp.4 2.4802416 0.9897652 0.3565632 0.1734301 ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell hash='ordination_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-6_434ee12f0a3959dcebfa6279bdb25e15'} ```{.r .cell-code} # loadings us_prin$loadings ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Loadings: Comp.1 Comp.2 Comp.3 Comp.4 Murder 0.536 0.418 0.341 0.649 Assault 0.583 0.188 0.268 -0.743 UrbanPop 0.278 -0.873 0.378 0.134 Rape 0.543 -0.167 -0.818 Comp.1 Comp.2 Comp.3 Comp.4 SS loadings 1.00 1.00 1.00 1.00 Proportion Var 0.25 0.25 0.25 0.25 Cumulative Var 0.25 0.50 0.75 1.00 ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell hash='ordination_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-7_94004d77823cff27aaad0afaad2611f7'} ```{.r .cell-code} # these scores should be the same, can't figure out why they're slightly different? us_prin$scores %>% head() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Comp.1 Comp.2 Comp.3 Comp.4 Alabama 0.9855659 1.1333924 0.44426879 0.156267145 Alaska 1.9501378 1.0732133 -2.04000333 -0.438583440 Arizona 1.7631635 -0.7459568 -0.05478082 -0.834652924 Arkansas -0.1414203 1.1197968 -0.11457369 -0.182810896 California 2.5239801 -1.5429340 -0.59855680 -0.341996478 Colorado 1.5145629 -0.9875551 -1.09500699 0.001464887 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} scale(USArrests) %*% us_eig$vectors %>% head() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [,1] [,2] [,3] [,4] Alabama -0.9756604 1.1220012 -0.43980366 0.154696581 Alaska -1.9305379 1.0624269 2.01950027 -0.434175454 Arizona -1.7454429 -0.7384595 0.05423025 -0.826264240 Arkansas 0.1399989 1.1085423 0.11342217 -0.180973554 California -2.4986128 -1.5274267 0.59254100 -0.338559240 Colorado -1.4993407 -0.9776297 1.08400162 0.001450164 ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell hash='ordination_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-8_4dbbb7077de667f9a14bb3a5c239ccec'} ```{.r .cell-code} # the scale variables cbind(us_prin$center, attr(scale(USArrests), "scaled:center")) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [,1] [,2] Murder 7.788 7.788 Assault 170.760 170.760 UrbanPop 65.540 65.540 Rape 21.232 21.232 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} n <- nrow(USArrests) cbind(us_prin$scale, attr(scale(USArrests), "scaled:scale") * sqrt((n-1) / n)) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [,1] [,2] Murder 4.311735 4.311735 Assault 82.500075 82.500075 UrbanPop 14.329285 14.329285 Rape 9.272248 9.272248 ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell hash='ordination_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-9_bff772fee9f4b1ecb182d01934f7333f'} ```{.r .cell-code} # covariance version us_prin_cov <- princomp(USArrests) # uses factor of 1/n for variance calculations # the svd equivalent n <- nrow(USArrests) us_svd_cov <- svd(cov(USArrests) * (n-1) / n) cbind(us_prin_cov$sdev^2, us_svd_cov$d) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [,1] [,2] Comp.1 6870.892554 6870.892554 Comp.2 197.952519 197.952519 Comp.3 41.270398 41.270398 Comp.4 6.040961 6.040961 ``` ::: ::: only works for when n > p, "R"-mode PCA refers to the respondents (rows) and "Q"-mode refers to the questions (columns). difference is just interpretation. SVD is prefered ### svd $$ \begin{aligned} \Sigma = UDV' \\ U'\Sigma = DV' \end{aligned} $$ ::: {.cell hash='ordination_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-10_ebfe2c11c4cd3f2f914e5f288e679f1a'} ```{.r .cell-code} us_Y <- cov(USArrests %>% scale(center = TRUE, scale = TRUE)) us_Y <- cor(USArrests) # the same as cov of centered matrix us_svd <- svd(us_Y) # UDV' # us_svd$u %*% diag(us_svd$d) %*% t(us_svd$v) us_svd$d # the variances ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 2.4802416 0.9897652 0.3565632 0.1734301 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} us_svd$v # the loadings ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [,1] [,2] [,3] [,4] [1,] -0.5358995 0.4181809 -0.3412327 0.64922780 [2,] -0.5831836 0.1879856 -0.2681484 -0.74340748 [3,] -0.2781909 -0.8728062 -0.3780158 0.13387773 [4,] -0.5434321 -0.1673186 0.8177779 0.08902432 ``` ::: ::: ::: ## Correspondence Analysis (CA) - `ca::ca()` - `FactoMineR::CA()` - `ade4::dudi.coa()` - `amap::afc()` - `MASS::corresp()` ::: {.cell hash='ordination_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-11_694919171f39218e393a42b34e3f0580'} ```{.r .cell-code} author_ca <- ca(author) plot(author_ca) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](ordination_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-11-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ## Multivariate Regression `lm` can handle multivariate regressions ### Estimation $$ \begin{aligned} \hat B = (X'X)^{-1}X'Y \end{aligned} $$ We can also formulate the answers w/ the centered $X$ matrix $$ \begin{aligned} \mathbf{\hat B_1} &= (\mathbf{X_c}'\mathbf{X_c})^{-1}\mathbf{X_c}'\mathbf{Y} \\ \mathbf{\hat \beta_0} &= \mathbf{\bar y} - \mathbf{\bar x}'\mathbf{\hat B_1} \end{aligned} $$ ::: {.cell hash='ordination_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-12_5b1912db5fbf115abb11aa970c335b72'} ```{.r .cell-code} iris_lm <- lm(cbind(Sepal.Length, Sepal.Width, Petal.Length, Petal.Width)~Species, data = iris) ``` ::: ::: {.cell hash='ordination_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-13_d07823342bbdcf943c62f52b6a4d70e2'} ```{.r .cell-code} # Useful for manual calculations Y <- with(iris, cbind(Sepal.Length, Sepal.Width, Petal.Length, Petal.Width)) X <- model.matrix(~Species, data = iris) X1 <- X[,-1] # drop the intercept Xc <- X1 %>% scale(scale = F) SYY <- cov(Y) SYX <- cov(Y, X1) SXX <- cov(X1) ``` ::: ::: {.cell hash='ordination_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-14_404af41c0be0da770992fee6529e2828'} ```{.r .cell-code} # Manual calculation of B B <- solve(crossprod(X)) %*% t(X) %*% Y # B # B calculation with centered matrices B1 <- solve(crossprod(Xc)) %*% t(Xc) %*% Y # B_1 B0 <- colMeans(Y) - t(colMeans(X1)) %*% B1 # B calculation w/ covariances B1_S <- solve(SXX) %*% t(SYX) B0_S <- colMeans(Y) - t(colMeans(X1)) %*% B1_S list(lm = coef(iris_lm), manual = B, centered = rbind(B0, B1), covariance = rbind(B0_S, B1_S)) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` $lm Sepal.Length Sepal.Width Petal.Length Petal.Width (Intercept) 5.006 3.428 1.462 0.246 Speciesversicolor 0.930 -0.658 2.798 1.080 Speciesvirginica 1.582 -0.454 4.090 1.780 $manual Sepal.Length Sepal.Width Petal.Length Petal.Width (Intercept) 5.006 3.428 1.462 0.246 Speciesversicolor 0.930 -0.658 2.798 1.080 Speciesvirginica 1.582 -0.454 4.090 1.780 $centered Sepal.Length Sepal.Width Petal.Length Petal.Width 5.006 3.428 1.462 0.246 Speciesversicolor 0.930 -0.658 2.798 1.080 Speciesvirginica 1.582 -0.454 4.090 1.780 $covariance Sepal.Length Sepal.Width Petal.Length Petal.Width 5.006 3.428 1.462 0.246 Speciesversicolor 0.930 -0.658 2.798 1.080 Speciesvirginica 1.582 -0.454 4.090 1.780 ``` ::: ::: $$ \begin{aligned} R^2 = \frac{|S_{XY} S_{XX}^{-1} S_{YX}|}{|S_{YY}|} \end{aligned} $$ ::: {.cell hash='ordination_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-15_cbf99f723f23e5a046a856291da1e4d4'} ```{.r .cell-code} # TODO: Why is R^2 zero here # R^2 from each regression # vapply(summary(iris_lm),FUN = function(x) x$r.squared, FUN.VALUE = numeric(1)) det(SYX %*% solve(SXX) %*% t(SYX)) / det(SYY) # way small, basically 0 ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 4.449697e-31 ``` ::: ::: ### Hypothesis Testing Consider the partitioning, from pg 343 of Rencher Methods of Multivariate Analysis $$ \begin{aligned} \mathbf{Y'Y} - n\mathbf{\bar y\bar y'} &= (\mathbf{Y'Y} + \mathbf{Y'X'\hat{B}}) - (\mathbf{Y'X'\hat{B}} - n\mathbf{\bar y\bar y'}) \\ &\equiv \mathbf{E} + \mathbf{H} \end{aligned} $$ In hypothesis testing, the matrix $E^{-1}H$ is pretty special, and many of the tests can be expressed in terms of the eigenvalues of this matrix. Hence, let $\lambda_i$ be the $i$th largest eigenvalue of $E^{-1}H$. - Wilks Hypothesis Test $\Lambda = \frac{|E|}{|E + H|}$ (likelihood ratio test) - on the eigenscale: $\Lambda = \prod_{i=1}^s \frac{1}{1+\lambda_i}$ - with covariance: $\Lambda = \frac{|\mathbf{S}|}{|\mathbf{S_{XX}}|\mathbf{S_{YY}}|}$ - Roy - on the eigenscale $\theta = \frac{\lambda_1}{1 + \lambda_1}$ - Pillai $V^{(s)} = \mathrm{tr}[(H + E)^{-1}H]$ - on the eigenscale: $V^{(s)} = \sum_i^s\frac{\lambda_i}{1 + \lambda_i}$ - Hotelling (generalized T statistic) $U^{(s)} = tr(E^{-1}H)$ - on the eigenscale: $U^{(s)} = \sum_i^s \lambda_i$ ## Redundancy Analysis Redundancy analysis can be understood as a multivariate regression followed by a PCA on the (covariance) of the fitted values. It seems I'm running into a bunch of singularity issues due to the fact that n < p in these matrices, the standard eigenequation of redundancy analysis is: $$ \begin{aligned} (S_{YX}S^{-1}_{XX}S'_{YX} - \lambda_k I)u_k = 0 \end{aligned} $$ The ecological matrix `dune` is matrix counts of 30 species (columns) from 20 sites (rows). The covariate matrix `dune.env` is covariates of the 20 sites (rows), with 5 features of the site (columns): - A1: numeric vector of soil thickness on A1 horizon - Moisture: ordered factor with levels 1 < 2 < 4 < 5 - Type of management - Use - land-use Hayfield < Hyapastu < Pasture - Manure - ordered factor ::: {.cell hash='ordination_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-16_eb0b33f3a6e458d5208d9674f78585f4'} observations with matrix $X$ ($n$ people by $p$ observations). The assumption is we can explain those The premise is that you can break down the covariance matrix into a systematic component (loadings) and an error. \begin{equation} X - M = \end{equation} ### Exploratory Factor Analysis $$ \hat \Sigma = \underbrace{\hat \Lambda\hat \Lambda^T}_{communality} + \underbrace{\hat \Psi}_{uniqueness} $$ #### Example [Introduction with practical example](https://www.geo.fu-berlin.de/en/v/soga/Geodata-analysis/factor-analysis/A-simple-example-of-FA/index.html) ::: {.cell hash='ordination_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-23_f05374a42ef5c25d375a6123baffb693'} ```{.r .cell-code} food <- read.csv("https://userpage.fu-berlin.de/soga/300/30100_data_sets/food-texture.csv", row.names = "X") # built in factor analysis (food.fa <- factanal(food, factors = 2)) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Call: factanal(x = food, factors = 2) Uniquenesses: Oil Density Crispy Fracture Hardness 0.334 0.156 0.042 0.256 0.407 Loadings: Factor1 Factor2 Oil -0.816 Density 0.919 Crispy -0.745 0.635 Fracture 0.645 -0.573 Hardness 0.764 Factor1 Factor2 SS loadings 2.490 1.316 Proportion Var 0.498 0.263 Cumulative Var 0.498 0.761 Test of the hypothesis that 2 factors are sufficient. The chi square statistic is 0.27 on 1 degree of freedom. The p-value is 0.603 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} food.fa$uniquenesses ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Oil Density Crispy Fracture Hardness 0.3338599 0.1555255 0.0422238 0.2560235 0.4069459 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} sum(food.fa$uniquenesses^2) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 0.3685864 ``` ::: ::: - R doesn't print loadings lower than .1 (to help spot common chunks) - Higher levels of uniqueness mean that the factors do not account well for its variance.
